Docs.summary: Common base class and contract for DataSourceProvider objects, which are factories that execute some queries to produce a single object or a list of objects that you can use as binding source objects.

remarks.format:
## Remarks DataSourceProvider is a convenience wrapper around an existing data model; it does not replace any data model. A data provider does not attempt to condense the complexity and versatility of a data model such as [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_ado](~/add/includes/tla2sharptla-ado-md.md)] into one single object with a few properties.
DataSourceProvider is an abstract class. Use one of the derived classes, which are <xref:System.Windows.Data.XmlDataProvider> and <xref:System.Windows.Data.ObjectDataProvider>. The DataSourceProvider is aware of the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_winclient](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)] threading and dispatcher model. It assumes the thread at creation time to be the [!INCLUDE[TLA2#tla_ui](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md)] thread. Events will get marshaled from a worker thread to the UI thread of the application.

Docs.summary: Starts the initial query to the underlying data model. The result is returned on the <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.Data%2A> property.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is typically called by the binding engine when dependent data bindings are activated. Set <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.IsInitialLoadEnabled%2A> to `false` to prevent or delay the automatic loading of data.
The InitialLoad method can be called multiple times. The provider ignores subsequent calls once it is busy executing the initial query; the provider does not restart an already running query when InitialLoad is called again. When the query finishes successfully, any InitialLoad call still does not re-query data. The InitialLoad operation is typically asynchronous, a <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.DataChanged> event is raised when the <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.Data%2A> property assumed a new value.
The application calls <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.Refresh%2A> to cause a refresh of the data.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether to prevent or delay the automatic loading of data.
Docs.value: to prevent or delay the automatic loading of data; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Typically the <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider> runs its query and sets its <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.Data%2A> property the first time it is used by a binding or a <xref:System.Windows.Data.CollectionViewSource>. You can omit this step by setting the IsInitialLoadEnabled property to `false`. In this case, the application must explicitly call <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.Refresh%2A> to cause the provider to obtain its data.

Docs.summary: Initiates a refresh operation to the underlying data model. The result is returned on the <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.Data%2A> property.

remarks.format: ## Remarks A refresh operation is typically asynchronous, a <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.DataChanged> event is raised when the <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.Data%2A> property assumed a new value. If the refresh operation fails, the <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.Data%2A> property is set to `null`; the <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.Error%2A> property is set with the error exception. The application can call Refresh while a previous refresh is still underway. Calling Refresh twice raises the <xref:System.Windows.Data.DataSourceProvider.DataChanged> event twice.
